questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room after using opioids. He reports that shortly after taking the drug, he felt an intense euphoria, which was soon followed by a state of deep sedation. What is the term used to describe this state of alternating euphoria and sedation?

A 22-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at a nightclub. On examination, he is disoriented, has a temperature of 39.5°C, and exhibits dilated pupils, tachycardia, and muscle rigidity. His friends report that he consumed a tablet given to him at the club. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A 45-year-old male with a 20-year history of smoking presents to the outpatient clinic. He admits that he is aware of the health risks associated with smoking but feels that he is not ready to quit at this time. However, he has started reading articles about smoking cessation. According to the Transtheoretical Model of Change, which stage of behavior change is he most likely in?
questions.explanation:
Precontemplation
  • The individual is not considering a change in behavior in the foreseeable future.
  • They may be unaware or in denial about the need for change.
  • In the scenario above, the patient is aware of the risks and is already exploring options, which rules out precontemplation. (Option A)

Contemplation
  • The individual recognizes the problem and is considering change, but is not yet ready to take action.
  • The patient in this case is aware of the health risks and is actively seeking information, which aligns with contemplation. They are ambivalent about quitting, indicating they are considering, but not committed to, change.

Preparation
  • The individual is intending to take action in the near future (usually within the next 30 days)
  • May have started taking small steps toward change.
  • This patient has not yet reached this stage, as he is still ambivalent and has not committed to making concrete plans to quit smoking. (Option C)

Action
  • The individual has recently made changes (within the last 6 months)
  • Actively working to maintain those changes.
  • Since the patient has not taken any steps to quit, he is not in the action stage. (Option D)

Maintenance
  • The individual has sustained their behavior change for more than 6 months
  • Working to prevent relapse.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man reports increasing financial troubles due to frequent horse racing bets. He's attempted to stop multiple times but fails, often betting more than intended. His job performance is suffering, and he's borrowed money from family under false pretenses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents with mood changes, increased anxiety, and difficulty sleeping, which have progressively worsened over the past week. He has a history of heavy smoking (30 cigarettes/day for 20 years) and quit smoking abruptly 8 days ago due to concerns about his health. Despite wanting to stay off cigarettes, he reports intense cravings, inability to focus, and feeling "on edge" all the time. He has attempted nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) in the past without success. Which of the following medications is most likely to help alleviate both his nicotine cravings and mood symptoms without causing significant weight gain?
questions.explanation:
The 5 A's Approach:

1. Ask

Record tobacco use status at every visit.

2. Advise

Strongly encourage quitting in a personalized way.

3. Assess

Determine if the patient is willing to quit at this time.

4. Assist

Use counseling and pharmacotherapy to help in quitting.

5. Arrange

Schedule follow-up within the first week after quitting.

Medication

Dosage

Mechanism of Action

Adverse Effects

Additional Info

Nicotine Replacement Therapies (NRTs)

Nicotine Replacement (NRT)

Patch (OTC)

Typically 6-12 weeks of maintenance, follow manufacturer guidelines

Delivers nicotine in controlled doses to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Skin irritation (patch), insomnia (24-hour patch).

Provides nicotine without harmful tobacco toxins. Combine well with gum for extra support.

Nicotine Gum/Lozenge

Oral (OTC)

2 mg for <25 cigarettes/day, 4 mg for >25 cigarettes/day

Replaces nicotine to ease withdrawal symptoms; absorbed via buccal mucosa.

Sore jaw (gum), heartburn, nausea, hiccups, headache.

Avoid acidic drinks during use as they reduce absorption.

Nicotine Nasal Spray/Inhaler

4 mg per cartridge (Inhaler); Nasal spray delivers rapid nicotine

Rapid delivery is similar to smoking, providing immediate relief from cravings.

Rhinitis, coughing, nasal irritation, watering eyes.

Useful for heavily dependent smokers but can cause irritation (rhinitis, coughing).

Non-Nicotine Medications:

Bupropion

150 mg once daily × 3 days, then 150 mg twice daily for 6-12 weeks

Norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI): Reduces cravings and withdrawal by modulating dopamine and norepinephrine.

Insomnia, dry mouth, nausea, risk of seizures (rare).

Antidepressant with dual effects on craving and mood.

Contraindicated in seizure disorders and eating disorders.

Varenicline(most effective)

Start with 0.5 mg once daily, increase to 1 mg twice daily

Partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic receptors: Alleviates withdrawal symptoms while blocking nicotine’s rewarding effects.

Nausea, insomnia, vivid dreams, neuropsychiatric symptoms (rare).

Reduces both cravings and the reinforcing effects of nicotine.

Monitor for neuropsychiatric or cardiac symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male, with a history of frequent cocaine use for the past 6 years, presents with intense fatigue, excessive sleep, increased appetite, and feelings of anhedonia. He states that he stopped using cocaine abruptly 3 days ago. On further questioning, he reports that over the past few months, his cocaine use had escalated to daily use. He also mentions experiencing intense cravings for cocaine and irritability but denies hallucinations or delusions. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic, and his vital signs are stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient at this stage?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate initiation of dopamine agonist therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of benzodiazepines to prevent withdrawal seizures

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought by his friends after collapsing at a party. He had been using a substance throughout the night that reportedly gave him a surge of euphoria and energy, but soon after, he started experiencing palpitations, intense sweating, and chest pain. On examination, his heart rate is 140 bpm, and his blood pressure is 190/120 mm Hg. The patient appears agitated and confused. His pupils are dilated. An ECG shows signs of acute myocardial ischemia. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of the substance this patient likely consumed?

A 22-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by his friends after exhibiting bizarre behavior at a party. He appears disoriented, has dilated pupils, and reports seeing vivid colors and patterns. His vital signs show tachycardia and mild hypertension. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Chemical nature

Synthetic base derived from lysergic acid nucleus from ergot alkaloids

Common forms

Tablets, liquid, blotter paper ("blotter acid")

Potency

100 µg of LSD ≈ 10-15 mg of psilocybin ≈ 300-400 mg of mescaline

Onset and duration

Onset within an hour, peaks in 2-4 hours, lasts 8-12 hours

Common physiologic symptoms

• Dilated pupils

• Increased deep tendon motor reflexes

• Muscle tension

• Mild motor incoordination

• Ataxia

Occasional physiologic symptoms

• Increased heart rate

• Increased respiration

• Hypertension

• Nausea

• Decreased appetite

• Salivation

• Sweating

• Blurred vision

Psychological effects

• Visual and perceptual changes

• Altered sense of time

• Mood changes

• Possible anxiety or paranoia

• Possible feelings of insight or creativity

Associated phenomenon

• Flashback phenomenon

• Badtrip (also seen with cannabis)

• Reflex hallucination/ morbid synesthesia (may occur with other hallucinogens)

Tolerance

Develops quickly (2-3 days of repeated use), lost after 4-6 days of abstinence

Potential risks

• Accidents due to impaired judgment

• Rarely, a syndrome similar to neuroleptic malignant syndrome

• Possible triggering of anxiety or depression in some users

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after exhibiting bizarre behavior in public. He appears disoriented, has nystagmus, and is expressing paranoid thoughts. His vital signs show hypertension and hyperthermia. Upon questioning, he admits to using a substance he calls "angel dust." Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Phencyclidine & Ketamine

Origin

Dissociative anesthetic agents; ketamine is closely related to PCP

Forms

Phencyclidine- Crystalline powder/paste added to cannabis or parsley-containing cigarettes

Ketamine- Powder or solution for intranasal, oral, inhalational, or intravenous use

Mechanism

Works at the NMDA receptor (as antagonist), causing hallucinations and dissociated state

Physical effects
  • Cardiovascular stimulation
  • No respiratory depression
  • Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Increased salivation
  • Nystagmus

Psychological effects
  • Altered sense of body and reality
  • Dissociative effects

Onset and duration

Phencyclidine- Effects occur in about 5 minutes, plateau in 30 minutes when smoked

Ketamine- Onset within seconds when used intravenously, analgesia lasting 40 minutes, dissociative effects for hours

Metabolism

N-demethylated by liver microsomal cytochrome P450 (CYP), especially CYP3A4, into norketamine

Detection

Phencyclidine- Detectable in urine & blood

Ketamine- Detectable in urine, with half-lives of 3, 4, and 7 hours for ketamine, norketamine, and dehydronorketamine respectively

Recent developments in usage

Phencyclidine- Not used clinically

Ketamine- Growing use in ketamine infusion clinics for depression treatment, FDA approval of esketamine nasal spray for treatment-resistant depression

Drug

Street Names

Cocaine

Coke, Blow, Snow, Nose candy

Heroin

Smack, H, Dope, Junk, Brown

Methamphetamine

Meth, Ice, Crystal, Tina

MDMA (Ecstasy)

Molly, E, XTC, Adam

Marijuana

Weed, Pot, Mary Jane, Bud

LSD

Acid, Lucy, Tabs, Trips

Prescription Opioids

Oxy, Hillbilly Heroin, Percs, Vikes

Benzodiazepines

Benzo, Xanax, Bars, Sleepers

Synthetic cannabinoids

Spice, K2, Black Mamba

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student presents to the university health center with complaints of anxiety, paranoid thoughts, and difficulty concentrating. He reports daily cannabis use for the past year. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

Key Features

Cannabis Use Disorder (Option D)

• Prolonged daily use of cannabis for weeks to months

• Risk increases with earlier age of first use and longer duration of use

• Affects approximately 1 in 10 cannabis users

Cannabis-Induced Psychotic Disorder (Option A)

• Rare occurrence of genuine psychotic process

• Transient paranoid ideation is more common

• "Florid psychosis" or "hemp insanity" in high potency cannabis use

• Often associated with preexisting personality disorders

Cannabis-Induced Anxiety Disorder

• Common during acute intoxication

• Short-lived anxiety states often provoked by paranoid thoughts

• May induce panic attacks

• More common in inexperienced users

Cognitive Impairment

• Long-term use may produce subtle cognitive impairments

• Affects memory, attention, and organization

• More pronounced with longer periods of heavy use

• Unclear if impairments resolve after extended abstinence

Amotivational Syndrome (Option C)

• Controversial cannabis-related syndrome

• Characterized by unwillingness to persist in tasks requiring prolonged attention

• Associated with long-term heavy use

• Individuals may become apathetic and anergic

Flashbacks

• Recurrence of sensations related to cannabis intoxication

• Can occur after short-term effects of the substance have disappeared

• Not known whether flashbacks are related to cannabis use alone or concomitant use of other substances

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of irritability, anxiety, and difficulty sleeping. He reports having been a daily cannabis user for the past 5 years but stopped abruptly 3 days ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line approach for managing this patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe benzodiazepines for anxiety and sleep

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate medically assisted withdrawal with cannabinoid agonists

questions.correct_answer: C. Provide supportive counseling and psychoeducation
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Onset and Duration

• Typically occurs 24-48 hours after cessation

• Most symptoms peak at days 2-6

• Can last up to 3 weeks or more in heavy users

Common Symptoms

• Irritability

• Anxiety

• Disturbed sleep/dreaming

• Depressed mood

• Loss of appetite

• Cannabis cravings

• Nervousness

• Restlessness

Less Common Symptoms

• Headaches

• Physical tension

• Sweating

• Chills

• Stomach pain

• Tremors

First-line Management

• Supportive counseling

• Psychoeducation about withdrawal symptoms

• Encouraging healthy coping strategies

Pharmacological Management

• No medications specifically approved for cannabis withdrawal

• Symptomatic treatment may be considered (e.g., for anxiety, sleep disturbances)

• Some agents (e.g., cannabinoid agonists) used off-label in clinical practice

Special Considerations

• Inpatient management may be indicated for patients with significant comorbid mental health disorders or polysubstance use

• Withdrawal symptoms may precipitate relapse to cannabis use

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by his roommate. The patient appears disoriented and anxious, with conjunctival injection and tachycardia. His roommate reports that they were experimenting with various forms of cannabis earlier in the evening. Which of the following statements about cannabis use and intoxication is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral ingestion of cannabis typically leads to a shorter duration of effects compared to inhalation

options.label: B
options.text: Cannabidiol (CBD) is the primary psychoactive component responsible for the "high" associated with cannabis use

options.label: C
options.text: Cannabinoid receptors are Gq subtype of G-protein coupled receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Tachycardia and conjunctival redness are common features of cannabis intoxication

questions.correct_answer: D. Tachycardia and conjunctival redness are common features of cannabis intoxication
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Composition

• Over 400 compounds

• Includes cannabinoids, flavonoids, and terpenoids

• Primary psychoactive component: Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)

Forms

• Dried plant material (marijuana)

• Bhang (Derived from dried leaves)

• Ganja (derived from flowering stem)

• Hashish (concentrated resin)

• Oils and extracts (Hash oil)

• Edibles

• Topical preparations

Receptors

CB1 and CB2 (G-protein coupled receptors- Gi subtype) (Option C)

Methods of Use

• Smoking (most common)

• Vaporizing

• Oral ingestion

• Sublingual administration

• Topical application

Clinical Features of Intoxication

• Tachycardia

• Conjunctival injection

• Anxiety or euphoria

• Slowness of time

• Impaired cognition and motor coordination

• Dry mouth

• Increased appetite

• Nystagmus

• Postural hypotension

• Delirium (especially at high doses)

Onset and Duration of Effects

• Smoking: Rapid onset (minutes), duration 2-3 hours

• Oral ingestion: Delayed onset (30-90 minutes), duration 4-12 hours

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with opioid use disorder presents with severe muscle aches, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, restlessness, and chills after stopping heroin "cold turkey." He has piloerection, dilated pupils, tachycardia, and mild hypertension. He refuses opioid for managing the withdrawals. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological treatment for his opioid withdrawal symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Opioid Withdrawal

Detoxification

Maintenance
  • Opioid Agents
  • Methadone: Opioid Agonist.
  • Buprenorphine:Partial Opioid Agonist.

Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST):

  • Methadone: Full opioid agonist
    • Improves treatment retention and reduces criminal behavior.
    • 80–120 mg/day.
    • Side effects: constipation, sweating, sexual dysfunction.
  • Buprenorphine:
    • Partial opioid agonist with a ceiling effect (limits overdose risk).
    • Combined with naloxone to prevent abuse.
    • Taken sublingually (tablet/film).
    • Side effects: constipation, nausea, drowsiness.
 
  • Opioid Antagonists (Naloxone, Naltrexone):
    • Naloxone: Reverses opioid overdose (emergency use).
    • Naltrexone: Blocks opioid effects to prevent euphoria, reduces opioid cravings. Available in oral and long-acting injectable forms.
    • Does not cause dependence or withdrawal but requires patient adherence.

Opioid addicted patient but unwilling to be treated with opioids: Symptomatic agents

  • Clonidine
    • Alpha-2 Adrenergic Agonist.
    • Reduces autonomic withdrawal symptoms- Sweating, Restlessness, Tremor or Rhinorrhea.
  • Anxiety: Benzodiazepines
  • Insomnia: Zolpidem
  • Musculoskeletal Pain: NSAIDs (Ibuprofen)
  • GI Symptoms: Antiemetic Diarrhea (Loperamide)

Pregnant Women with Opioid Use Disorder:

  • Illicit opioid use during pregnancy increases risks for both mother and baby
  • Methadone or buprenorphine maintenance reduces risks, though neonatal opioid withdrawal may still occur.
  • Associated risks- Neonatal infections (HIV), premature labor, low birth weight, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

Psychotherapy Modalities/ Non- Pharmacological Treatment:

  • Effective treatments: Individual therapy, CBT, family therapy, support groups (NA), and social skills training.
  • Social skills training is key for patients with poor social skills.
  • Residential programs for people with substance use disorders.
  • Education on HIV transmission and safe sex is essential.
  • Needle-exchange programs, where available, help reduce unsafe needle sharing and associated infections.
  • Narcotics Anonymous (NA): A 12-step self-help group for abstinent drug addicts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found unresponsive on the floor of his apartment by a friend. Upon arrival, emergency medical personnel observe the following: the patient has a weak pulse, slow and shallow respirations, and pinpoint pupils. His skin is cold and clammy, and there are needle track marks on his arms. His blood pressure is significantly low. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer intravenous naloxone at a rapid rate

options.label: B
options.text: Ensure an adequate airway and mechanically ventilate the patient

options.label: C
options.text: Give intravenous fluids to manage hypotension

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a CT scan to rule out intracranial hemorrhage

questions.correct_answer: B. Ensure an adequate airway and mechanically ventilate the patient
questions.explanation:
Opioid Toxicity

Clinical features

Treatment
  • Clinical Triad

 
  • Opioid overdose often leads to respiratory arrest.
  • Symptoms include marked unresponsiveness, coma, slow respiration, hypothermia, hypotension, and bradycardia
  • Inspect for needle tracks in arms, legs, ankles, groin, and dorsal vein of the penis.
  • Ensure an adequate airway; aspirate secretions if needed.
  • Use mechanical ventilation until naloxone is given.
  • Drug of Choice: Intravenous Naloxone
  • Opioid Antagonist which is a short acting.
  • Given at a slow rate of 0.8 mg/70 kg of body weight. (Option A)
  • Signs of improvement
    • Increase respiratory rate
    • Pupillary Dilation
  • If there is no response after the initial dose, repeat naloxone every few minutes.
  • If no response after 4-5 mg, consider nonopioid substances as factors.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought by her family. They report that over the past year, she has been using increasing amounts of opioids, initially prescribed for chronic back pain. The patient admits to using opioids in larger amounts than intended and has made several unsuccessful attempts to cut down. She has given up her hobbies and often misses work due to opioid use. Recently, she was arrested for stealing prescription pads from her doctor's office. Despite these issues, she continues to use opioids daily. Which of the following statements BEST characterizes this patient's condition based on the information provided?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient meets criteria for opioid dependence, with evidence of tolerance and withdrawal

options.label: B
options.text: The patient exhibits opioid abuse but does not meet the full criteria for dependence due to the absence of physiological symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: The patient meets the criteria for opioid dependence, with prominent features of impaired control and social impairment

options.label: D
options.text: The patient's behavior suggests opioid misuse rather than dependence, as the initial use was medically sanctioned

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient meets the criteria for opioid dependence, with prominent features of impaired control and social impairment
questions.explanation:
Type of Dependence

Definition

Behavioral Dependence

Focuses on substance-seeking behaviors and the patterns of pathological use.

Physical Dependence

Refers to the physiological effects that result from repeated episodes of substance use.

Psychological Dependence

Also called habituation, characterized by a persistent or occasional craving to avoid dysphoria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of alcohol use disorder presents for treatment. He has recently been diagnosed with compensated liver failure. The patient expresses a strong desire to quit drinking and is motivated to maintain abstinence. His medical history includes no liver failure, and he is currently not consuming alcohol. Which pharmacological treatment is the most appropriate for this patient to help manage his alcohol cravings?
questions.explanation:
Anticraving Agents

Acamprosate

Naltrexone
  • NMDA Antagonist and positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors.
  • Given after stopping the consumption of alcohol.
  • Contraindicated in severe Renal Impairment.
  • In moderate renal impairment (given in reduced doses).
  • FDA approved.
  • Opioid Antagonist.
  • Can be started when a patient is consuming alcohol or in withdrawal phase.
  • Contraindicated in Liver Failure. (Option C)
  • Check LFTs periodically.
  • FDA approved.

Other anti craving Agents are which are not FDA approved but effective:

  • Ondansetron (5HT-3 Antagonist) (Option D)
  • Topiramate (Anti Epileptic agent)
  • Baclofen (GABA-B Agonist)
  • Fluoxetine (SSRI)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder presents after abrupt cessation of drinking. He shows anxiety, tremors, and experiences a seizure. Which medication would be most appropriate for managing his withdrawal symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal (Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening (Delirium Tremens)
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs): Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower seizure threshold.

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioral approaches recommended.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine evaluation after his friends expressed concern about his drinking habits. He reports consuming alcohol heavily for several years. The physician orders laboratory tests to assess his alcohol intake. Which test result is most indicative of his heavy alcohol consumption?
questions.explanation:
Laboratory tests in Alcoholism

γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT)
  • >35.0 U/L
  • Chronic alcohol abuse
  • Elevated GGT levels indicate liver disease and are often found in chronic heavy drinkers, but only 30–50% of excessive drinkers show elevated levels (Option C).
  • Not specific to alcohol use, as other conditions like pancreatitis and prostate disease can also raise its levels.

Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT)
  • >3.0%
  • Most important biomarker for heavy alcohol intake. (Option D)
  • Good sensitivity and specificity.

Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
  • >91.0 μm3
  • Heavy alcohol use
  • MCV levels can remain elevated for several months after someone stops drinking, meaning a person may be abstinent yet still have a high MCV value. (Option A)

Serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase (alanine aminotransferase)- ALT
  • >45.0 IU/L
  • Chronic alcohol abuse
  • More specific marker of alcohol-induced liver injury since it is mainly located in the liver. (Option B)

Serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase

(aspartate aminotransferase)- AST
  • >45.0 IU/L
  • Chronic alcohol abuse
  • The AST to ALT ratio helps confirm heavy alcohol consumption. (Ratio >2 is correlated with alcoholic liver disease)

N-Acetyl-β-Hexosaminidase (Beta-Hex)
  • Increased beta-Hex subsides to normal levels after only 7 to 10 days of abstinence.
  • Diabetes and hypertension also elevate beta-Hex.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits a sleep specialist due to persistent insomnia. He mentions that he often drinks alcohol in the evenings, believing it helps him sleep better. After discussing his sleep patterns, the specialist explains that alcohol has several effects on sleep quality and architecture. Which of the following is not an effect of alcohol on sleep?

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased deep sleep due to its sedative properties

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents to the emergency with sudden onset loss of consciousness and seizures. He also shows signs of confusion, apathy, dementia, visual hallucinations and aggressive behavior. An MRI is performed, revealing the findings shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is referred to a psychiatrist after he exhibits significant memory impairment, particularly anterograde amnesia, and frequently confabulates to fill memory gaps. After initial stabilization, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate thiamine supplementation at 100 mg, 2-3 times/day

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate thiamine supplementation at 100 mg, 2-3 times/day
questions.explanation:
Korsakoff syndrome

Onset

Chronic progression of Wernicke Encephalopathy

Symptoms
  • Impaired recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia: More common, inability to form new memories.
  • Retrograde amnesia: Inability to recall old memories.
  • Confabulation: Making false stories to fill memory gaps. These are unintentional.

Cause

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency

Neuropathologic Lesions

Symmetrical involvement of:

  • Mammillary bodies
  • Thalamus, Hypothalamus
  • Midbrain
  • Pons
  • Medulla
  • Cerebrum

Treatment
  • Supplementation of Thiamine 100 mg, 2-3 times/day for 3-12 months.
  • Full recovery is only seen in 20% of patients, others see partial improvement and symptoms may not completely resolve.
  • If patients do not respond to Thiamine: Consider Alcohol Pellagra Encephalopathy and treat with Niacin. (Option B)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism is brought to the emergency department by his family. They report that he has been confused and unsteady on his feet for the past two days. On examination, the patient is disoriented and has difficulty maintaining his balance. You also notice bilateral nystagmus and weakness in his lateral eye movements. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Korsakoff Syndrome

Onset

Acute

Chronic, often follows Wernicke's

Key Symptoms

• Global Confusion

• Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)

• Ataxia (especially gait)

• Severe anterograde amnesia

• Retrograde amnesia

• Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus,midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a 20-year history of daily alcohol use is admitted to the hospital for pneumonia. Two days after admission, he becomes agitated and reports seeing insects crawling on the walls. His vital signs show tachycardia (HR 110 bpm), hypertension (BP 160/95 mmHg), and a fever of 38.2°C (100.8°F). He is disoriented and tremulous. Which of the following is the most accurate statement about this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: He is experiencing early symptoms of alcohol withdrawal

options.label: B
options.text: He is likely developing Wernicke's encephalopathy

options.label: C
options.text: He is showing signs of delirium tremens

options.label: D
options.text: His symptoms are typical of impending alcohol withdrawal seizures

questions.correct_answer: C. He is showing signs of delirium tremens
questions.explanation:
Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal

• Mild anxiety

• Tremulousness

• Nausea

• Headache

• Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)

• Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations

• Intact orientation

• Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)

• Generalized tonic-clonic seizures

• Usually brief and self-limited

• Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life threatening (Delirium tremens)

• Severe agitation

• Confusion and disorientation

• Hallucinations (often visual)

• Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)

• Profound sweating

• Tremors

• Insomnia

Within 72 hours

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at a party. His friends report that he consumed a large amount of alcohol over a short period. On examination, the patient is unresponsive to verbal stimuli, has irregular breathing, and a heart rate of 50 beats per minute. Which range of blood alcohol concentration (in mg/dL) is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
BAC (mg/dL)

Effects

20-30 (Option A)

Slowed motor performance and decreased thinking ability

30-80 (Option B)

Increase in motor and cognitive problems

80-200 (Option C)

Increase in incoordination and judgment errors, mood lability, deterioration in cognition

200-300

Nystagmus, marked slurring of speech, and alcoholic blackouts

>300

Impaired vital signs and possible death

questions.text: Which of the following statements about alcohol absorption and metabolism is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of alcohol absorption occurs in the stomach

options.label: B
options.text: Peak Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) is typically reached within 5-10 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: Consuming alcohol with food accelerates its absorption

options.label: D
options.text: Only less than 10% is excreted unchanged in breath, sweat, and urine

questions.correct_answer: D. Only less than 10% is excreted unchanged in breath, sweat, and urine
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Absorption
  • 20% absorbed through stomach
  • 80% absorbed through small intestine (Option A)
  • Faster absorption on empty stomach, slower absorption if consumed after food intake (Option C)

Distribution
  • Distributed throughout water-containing portions of body
  • Affects organs with high water content (e.g. liver, brain)

Metabolism
  • Primary site is liver
  • Enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase converts alcohol to acetaldehyde
  • Further, acetaldehyde is converted into acetate by enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase
  • <10% excreted unchanged in breath, sweat, and urine
  • Remaining ~90% metabolized by liver

Factors Affecting Kinetics
  • Food in stomach (slows absorption)
  • Body weight and composition
  • Gender (females generally reach higher BAC)
  • Genetics (e.g. ADH enzyme variants)
  • Tolerance in chronic drinkers

Blood Alcohol Curve
  • Sharp rise during absorption phase
  • Peak at 45-90 minutes after drinking (Option B)
  • Slow decline during distribution phase
  • Faster decline during elimination phase
  • Mellanby effect- more intoxicating effects when BAC is increasing than for the same BAC when decreasing

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after heavy alcohol consumption. His blood alcohol concentration (BAC) was recorded at two different times: once when it was rising to 100 mg/dL and later when it was falling to the same level. The physician noted that the patient appeared more intoxicated during the rising phase of BAC compared to the falling phase, even though the BAC was identical at both points. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
A 28-year-old male presents with a long-standing history of cocaine abuse. Which of the following best explains the etiology and maintenance of his substance use disorder?

options.label: B
options.text: Alexithymia leading to self-medication with cocaine

options.label: C
options.text: Conditioned learning and neuroplasticity in the brain-reward circuitry

options.label: D
options.text: Modulation of the GABA system resulting in tolerance

questions.correct_answer: C. Conditioned learning and neuroplasticity in the brain-reward circuitry
questions.explanation:
Biological Factors

Genetic Predisposition
  • Studies of twins, adoptees, and siblings indicate a strong genetic component, particularly in alcohol use disorders.
  • Genetic factors may influence neurotransmitter systems, affecting an individual's response to substances.

Neurochemical Changes
  • SUDs involve alterations in brain neurotransmitter systems, particularly:
    • Dopaminergic system: Critical in the brain's reward circuitry
    • Opioid system: Involved in pain modulation and reward
    • GABA system: Implicated in anxiety reduction and sedation
  • The ventral tegmental area (VTA) and its projections to the nucleus accumbens are key in the brain-reward circuitry.

Neuroplasticity
  • Repeated substance use leads to adaptive changes in the brain, affecting:
    • Neurotransmitter release
    • Receptor function
    • Second-messenger systems
    • Gene regulation

Psycho-

logical Factors

Learning and Conditioning
  • Operant conditioning: Substance use is reinforced by its consequences (e.g., euphoria, relief from negative states).
  • Classical conditioning: Environmental cues associated with substance use can trigger craving or withdrawal symptoms.

Cognitive Factors
  • Beliefs about substance effects
  • Expectations of drug-related outcomes
  • Impaired decision-making processes

Mental Health
  • Pre-existing mental health issues may contribute to substance use as a form of self-medication.
  • Some individuals may have difficulty recognizing or expressing emotions (alexithymia), potentially leading to substance use.

Environmental/

Social Factors

Social
  • Peer pressure and social norms
  • Family dynamics and modeling of substance use behavior
  • Cultural attitudes towards substance use

Availability and Accessibility
  • Ease of obtaining substances
  • Exposure to drug-using environments

Stress and Life Events
  • Chronic stress or traumatic experiences may increase vulnerability to substance use.

Interplay of Factors

  
  • Initial use may be influenced by environmental factors (e.g., availability, peer pressure).
  • Continued use is affected by individual biology and psychology (e.g., how drug effects are perceived, and the development of tolerance).
  • Progression to dependence involves neuroadaptive changes, learning processes, and environmental reinforcement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency room after consuming a large quantity of alcohol during a party. He mentions that this was the first time he drank so much, and he was urged by friends to continue drinking. He has no history of alcohol use before this event, and he assures that he does not intend to consume alcohol regularly. His physical exam reveals elevated blood pressure, nausea, and mild confusion. His liver function tests are slightly elevated. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Single episode of harmful use
